metadata.title: Tax Optimization for Options Traders
metadata.description: Tax strategies, Section 1256 contracts, wash sale rules, and optimization techniques

chunks.content: Section 1256 contracts include regulated futures contracts, foreign currency contracts, non-equity options, dealer equity options, and dealer securities futures contracts. These receive special tax treatment: 60% of gains taxed as long-term capital gains (max 20%), 40% as short-term (up to 37%). This applies regardless of holding period. SPX, XSP, and other index options qualify. ETF options (SPY, QQQ) do NOT qualify - they're taxed as regular short-term/long-term gains. Blended rate for Section 1256: approximately 26.8% vs potentially 37% for short-term trades.
chunks.key_insight: Trade index options (SPX, XSP) instead of ETF options (SPY, QQQ) for significant tax savings on short-term trades.
chunks.application: Our cash-secured put strategy on SPY pays short-term rates. Consider switching to SPX or XSP puts for 60/40 treatment and ~10% tax savings on gains.
chunks.embedding_text: Section 1256 contracts 60/40 rule tax treatment. Index options SPX XSP qualified 60% long-term 40% short-term. ETF options SPY QQQ not qualified regular tax rates. Blended rate 26.8% vs 37% short-term. Trade index options for tax savings.

chunks.content: The wash sale rule disallows loss deductions if you buy 'substantially identical' securities within 30 days before or after selling at a loss. For options: buying a call after selling stock at loss, buying stock after selling put at loss, or rolling options can trigger wash sales. The disallowed loss gets added to the cost basis of the new position. CRITICAL: Wash sales apply across ALL your accounts (IRA, brokerage, spouse accounts). Options on the same underlying are generally considered substantially identical.
chunks.key_insight: A loss is not 'lost' - it increases your cost basis. But it delays the tax benefit, which has time-value cost.
chunks.application: When rolling losing options positions, be aware the loss may be disallowed. Consider waiting 31 days before re-entering similar positions if tax-loss harvesting is important.
chunks.embedding_text: wash sale rule 30-day trap substantially identical securities. Buy within 30 days before or after selling loss disallowed. Options same underlying substantially identical. Loss added to cost basis new position. Applies across all accounts IRA brokerage spouse.

chunks.topic: Straddle Rules - When Hedging Creates Tax Issues
chunks.content: IRS straddle rules apply when you hold offsetting positions that substantially diminish risk of loss. Effects: (1) Losses on one leg may be deferred until other leg closed. (2) Holding period suspended for long positions. (3) Interest/carrying costs may not be deductible. Identified straddles allow some relief if you properly identify positions. Qualified covered calls are exempt from straddle rules if: (1) Call is out-of-money, (2) Expires in less than 12 months, (3) No downside protection purchased.
chunks.key_insight: Complex hedged positions can create unexpected tax consequences. Simple strategies (naked puts, covered calls) have cleaner tax treatment.
chunks.application: Our simple cash-secured put strategy avoids straddle rule complexity. If implementing collar strategies, be aware of straddle implications.
chunks.embedding_text: straddle rules hedging tax issues offsetting positions diminish risk loss. Losses deferred holding period suspended. Identified straddles relief. Qualified covered calls exempt out-of-money less than 12 months. Simple strategies cleaner tax treatment.

chunks.content: When options are exercised/assigned, the premium becomes part of the stock transaction: CALL SOLD (covered call): Premium added to sale price. If assigned, long-term/short-term depends on stock holding period. PUT SOLD (cash-secured put): Premium reduces cost basis of acquired shares. Holding period starts at assignment. CALL BOUGHT: Premium added to cost basis of purchased shares. PUT BOUGHT: If exercised, premium subtracted from sale proceeds. Key insight: Assignment is NOT a taxable event for the option itself - it merges into the stock transaction.
chunks.key_insight: Cash-secured put premium reduces your cost basis when assigned, improving your breakeven and future gain/loss calculation.
chunks.application: When our CSP is assigned, the premium collected reduces our cost basis. Example: $50 strike, $2 premium collected = $48 effective cost basis.
chunks.embedding_text: option assignment tax treatment premium stock transaction. Covered call premium added sale price. Cash-secured put premium reduces cost basis. Assignment not taxable event merges stock transaction. CSP assigned premium reduces cost basis breakeven.

chunks.content: Tax loss harvesting involves selling losing positions to offset gains. With options: (1) Close losing options before year-end. (2) Use losses to offset gains from winning trades. (3) Up to $3,000 excess losses can offset ordinary income. (4) Remaining losses carry forward indefinitely. Strategy: In December, review all positions. Close losers to harvest losses. Wait 31 days before similar positions (wash sale). Consider 'doubling down' before selling - buy similar position, wait 31 days, then sell original at loss (requires capital).
chunks.key_insight: Harvest losses strategically in December. $3,000 ordinary income offset = ~$1,000 tax savings at 33% bracket.
chunks.application: Before year-end, review all options positions. Harvest losses on losers. Use gains from ETF accumulation strategy to offset if needed.
chunks.embedding_text: tax loss harvesting options selling losing positions offset gains. Close losers before year-end. $3,000 excess offset ordinary income. Carry forward indefinitely. December review harvest losses wait 31 days wash sale.

chunks.content: IRS allows qualifying traders to elect mark-to-market (Section 475) treatment: All positions marked to market at year-end. All gains/losses treated as ordinary (not capital). No wash sale rules apply. Losses fully deductible (no $3,000 cap). Requirements for TTS: (1) Substantial trading activity, (2) Trade nearly every day, (3) Seek to profit from short-term swings, (4) Significant time devoted to trading. Election must be filed by April 15 of the prior year. Most retail traders don't qualify - requires near full-time trading activity.
chunks.key_insight: TTS is powerful but hard to qualify for. Most algorithmic traders using daily strategies may qualify. Consult tax professional.
chunks.application: Our automated daily trading system may eventually qualify for TTS if we trade substantial volume. For now, we're investors subject to normal rules.
chunks.embedding_text: trader tax status TTS mark-to-market Section 475 election. Mark positions year-end ordinary gains losses. No wash sale rules losses fully deductible. Requirements substantial activity trade daily short-term swings. Election April 15 prior year. Most retail don't qualify.

chunks.topic: Options Trading in IRAs - Tax-Advantaged Strategies
chunks.content: IRAs allow limited options strategies: Traditional IRA allows covered calls, cash-secured puts, protective puts. NO margin, NO naked options, NO spreads in most IRAs. Tax advantage: All gains tax-deferred (traditional) or tax-free (Roth). No wash sale tracking needed. No tax on assignment/exercise. Best strategies for IRA: Cash-secured puts (income generation), Covered calls (yield enhancement), Protective puts (hedging). Our $10/day strategy works perfectly in IRA - all gains compound tax-free.
chunks.key_insight: Roth IRA is ideal for aggressive strategies - all gains tax-free forever. Traditional IRA defers taxes on option income.
chunks.application: Consider running our CSP and ETF accumulation strategy in Roth IRA for tax-free compounding.
chunks.embedding_text: options trading IRA tax-advantaged strategies. Traditional IRA covered calls cash-secured puts protective puts. No margin naked options spreads. Tax-deferred traditional tax-free Roth. No wash sale tracking. Roth IRA aggressive strategies gains tax-free forever.

chunks.topic: Essential Record Keeping for Options Traders
chunks.content: Required records for IRS compliance: (1) Trade date, settlement date for every transaction. (2) Cost basis and proceeds for every trade. (3) Option type, strike, expiration. (4) Assignment/exercise details. (5) Wash sale adjustments. (6) Total gains/losses by category. Brokers provide 1099-B but may not track wash sales across accounts. Keep own records for: Multi-account wash sale tracking, Cost basis adjustments from assignments, Section 1256 vs regular options separation. Use trade journal or spreadsheet. Our system logs all trades to data/trades_*.json - ensure this includes all required tax fields.
chunks.key_insight: Broker 1099-B is starting point, not gospel. You're responsible for accurate reporting including cross-account wash sales.
chunks.application: Our trade logging system should capture all tax-relevant fields. Add cost basis tracking and wash sale flagging to future enhancements.
